channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Venezuelan Court Blocks 4 Lawmakers
item.description: The move, in response to a challenge from a candidate in the governing Socialist party, blocked three from the opposition and one Socialist just days before a new National Assembly was to be sworn in.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN and PATRICIA TORRES

item.title: Muslims on Twitter Say They Have Better Things to Do Than Join ISIS
item.description: Play video games, see “Star Wars,” wash the dishes: Muslims respond to the Islamic State leader’s rallying cry with defiance, opposition and sarcasm.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MARCUS

item.title: In 2015 Obituaries, a Portrait of Eras Grim and Innocent
item.description: Some of the people whose lives were chronicled in The Times this year sought fame. Others were surprised by it. But all left a lasting impact.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM McDONALD
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: The Kobal Collection/Riama-Pathé; James Estrin/The New York Times; John Shearer/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Getty Images; Sam Falk/The New York Times; Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Anita Ekberg in "La Dolce Vita," the 1960 film; Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on the campaign trail in 1994; B.B. King in 1972; Yogi Berra in 1956; and E.L. Doctorow in New York City in 1989.

item.title: Open Source: Caetano Veloso Loves Israel, but Won’t Be Going Back
item.description: One of Brazil’s most revered singers says his stance on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has been widely misunderstood.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Climate Chaos, Across the Map
item.description: A powerful El Niño climate pattern washes out what was the hottest year ever recorded on the surface of the planet, leaving experts trying to decipher all the factors behind the odd weather extremes of 2015.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: Waiting out the flood Wednesday in Dumfries, Scotland, after heavy rain.

item.title: Egypt Officials Stop Facebook Program for Free Access to Internet
item.description: The program, Free Basics, began in October and had drawn more than three million Egyptians.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Iran’s Missile Tests Remind the U.S. That Hostilities Have Not Ended
item.description: There is almost no doubt that the nuclear accord will go into effect, but an era of broad co-operation between Washington and Tehran remains distant.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Mass Communication Specialist 3Rd Class J. M. Tolbert/U.S. Navy, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The aircraft carrier Harry S. Truman in the Gulf of Oman on Friday.

item.title: Cellphone Contacts in Paris Attacks Suggest Foreign Coordination
item.description: Police reports that assailants in Paris were in cellphone contact with at least one person in Belgium during the attacks challenge the assumption that one of them was the chief planner.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Sinosphere: Biding Time Until China’s Outlook Clears
item.description: A slowing economy, a campaign against corruption and the Communist Party’s grip on intellectual life left the nation in a state of waiting.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A paramilitary officer wearing a mask to shield against heavy pollution in Tiananmen Square in Beijing last week.

item.title: Anselm Kiefer and His Hallmarks Have a Moment
item.description: A retrospective in Paris delves into the career of Mr. Kiefer, a German artist with a new apocalyptic installation at the Pompidou Center.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:description: Anselm Kiefer in the new installation for his retrospective at the Pompidou Center in Paris.

item.title: Georgia Lawmakers Approve a New Prime Minister
item.description: Lawmakers in Georgia, a former Soviet republic, voted late Tuesday to approve Giorgi Kvirikashvili as prime minister amid popular dissatisfaction with the government.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: World Briefing: World Leaders Agree to Extend Efforts to End Ukraine Conflict
item.description: The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, France and Germany called for the Minsk peace agreement to be carried out in full in 2016.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA ODYNOVA

item.title: Brussels Police Investigate Reports of Police Orgy Amid Terror Alert
item.description: A newspaper reported an account of an alcohol-fueled “orgy” among soldiers and officers at a police station last month while Brussels was nearly shut down after the Paris massacre.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER
item.media:description: Police officers secured an area of Brussels last month. The authorities have started an internal investigation into reports that an orgy took place at a local police station while the region was on high alert.

item.title: Belgium Arrests 2 Linked to New Year’s Eve Plot to Attack Brussels
item.description: In a series of raids, the authorities found Islamic State propaganda and military-style hardware and computer equipment in the homes of the two suspects.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER

item.title: Russia Expands Sanctions Against Turkey After Downing of Jet
item.description: The additional measures bar Turkish construction companies from signing new contracts after Jan. 1, and also prohibit Turkish citizens or companies from operating tourism agencies in Russia.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Video taken at the Turkey-Syria border showing the Russian aircraft that was shot down. Russia reacted by imposing sanctions, including canceling energy projects and banning fruit and vegetable imports.

item.title: Turkey’s Campaign Against Kurdish Militants Takes Toll on Civilians
item.description: Several Turkish cities are under lock down, hundreds of thousands are displaced, while others are trapped without food or electricity as violent clashes intensify.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Militants of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, or P.K.K., guarded a barricade in Sirnak, Turkey.

item.title: Investigators Blame Violent Weather for Yangtze Cruise Ship Disaster
item.description: But a Chinese government inquiry also found fault with the captain and dozens of officials, because of poor decisions and laxity.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Chinese rescue workers righting the capsized Oriental Star cruise ship, in Jianli County, Hubei Province, in June. All but a dozen of the hundreds on board died in the disaster.

item.title: Central African Republic Elections, Long Delayed, Are Peaceful
item.description: Citizens have begun casting ballots in what could represent the best hope of reuniting the country, one of the world’s poorest, after three years of sectarian violence.
item.dc:creator: MARGAUX BENN
item.media:description: Voters lined up outside a polling station in the PK5 neighborhood of Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic, on Wednesday.

item.title: Kabul Journal: After Taliban Attack in Kabul, a Music Teacher Keeps Playing
item.description: Ahmad Naser Sarmast has not fully regained the hearing in his left ear after a suicide blast, but that has not slowed his mission to bring music to children.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Ahmad Naser Sarmast of the Afghanistan National Institute of Music at a 2013 concert in Kabul. A suicide bombing at a concert in 2014 wounded him and killed a man near him.

item.title: Turkey Detains 2 ISIS Militants Planning New Year’s Eve Attack
item.description: The pair were plotting a suicide attack on Kizilay Square in Ankara, where crowds gather to usher in the new year, a senior government official said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
